definition:
A topological space $(X,\tau)$ is said to be $T_0$ (or to satisfy the
$T_0$ axiom ) if for all distinct $x,y\in X$ there exists an open set
$U\in\tau$ such that either $x\in U$ and $y\notin U$ or $x\notin U$ and
$y\in U$.

All are $T_0$. An example of $T_0$ space that is not $T_1$ is the
$2$-point Sierpinski space.
